metadata.case_name: Sardar Gian Singh v. State of Punjab

facts.text: Appellant recruited in 1927 as Naib Tehsildar in Revenue department of Province of Punjab, confirmed in 1939.
In 1946, promoted to officiating Tehsildar, posted as Tehsildar at Hansi in Hissar district on September 22, 1947, thereafter held post at diverse places.
On August 20, 1952, served with charge sheet by Financial Commissioner, Punjab containing eleven heads of charges of misappropriation, misconduct, irregularities and dereliction of duties.
Deputy Commissioner, Hissar appointed to hold departmental enquiry into charges.
On August 28, 1953, served with notice to show cause why he should not be dismissed on findings of enquiry officer; submitted explanation.
Financial Commissioner by order dated October 26, 1953 ordered dismissal from service.
Appeal against dismissal order dismissed; application to Government of Punjab for revision dismissed.

Petition under Art. 226 to Punjab High Court quashing dismissal; Bishan Narain J. rejected plea on reasonable opportunity but held Financial Commissioner incompetent due to amendment of Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation Order 1937; allowed petition.
Letters Patent Appeal No. 82 of 1957 by State; Division Bench reversed single judge, held rules continued by cls. 9 and 10 of Adaptation Order 1937; dismissed petition.
Appeal to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 133.

Section 9 Punjab Land Revenue Act 1887 originally: Provincial Government fix number of Tehsildars/Naib Tehsildars; Financial Commissioner make rules for appointment and dismissal. Rules framed 1932 under s.9 read with s.28 conferring authority on Financial Commissioner.
Post GOI Act 1935, s.9 amended by Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937 deleting words after 'appointed'; s.28 amended entrusting power to Provincial Government.
Punjab Civil Services Rules framed in 1941 by Governor under s.241 GOI Act 1935; r.1(4) not apply to persons with special provision by law.

legal_issues.text: Whether Financial Commissioner had authority to dismiss the appellant Tehsildar in 1953, given amendments to Punjab Land Revenue Act by Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937 and effect of GOI Act 1935, Transitory Provisions Order 1936, and Punjab Civil Services Rules 1941.
Whether Tehsildari Rules 1932 continued in force post-1937 amendments and 1941 Civil Services Rules.

petitioner_arguments.text: Reasonable opportunity not given before enquiry officer or Financial Commissioner to rebut charges.
Financial Commissioner incompetent to dismiss as power to make rules under s.9 Punjab Land Revenue Act abrogated by 1937 Adaptation Order; rules invalid post-amendment.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Punjab Land Revenue Act s.9; Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937

petitioner_arguments.text: Tehsildari Rules 1932 superseded by Punjab Civil Services Rules 1941; no delegation to Financial Commissioner; Tehsildars under Subordinate Services Class III.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: GOI Act 1935 s.241; Punjab Civil Services Rules 1941 r.1.4, Ch.XV r.2.14

petitioner_arguments.text: Post GOI Act 1935, dismissal power vested only in Governor; cls.9,10 Adaptation Order do not save rules inconsistent with s.241.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: GOI Act 1935 s.241(2); Adaptation Order cls.7,9,10

respondent_arguments.text: Tehsildari Rules 1932 continued by cls.9 and 10 of Adaptation Order 1937; Financial Commissioner retained power to dismiss.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Adaptation of Indian Laws Order 1937 cls.9,10; GOI Act 1935 ss.292,293

respondent_arguments.text: Conditions of service continued unaltered by Transitory Provisions Order 1936 cl.15(2) and Adaptation Order cl.12(d).
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: GOI Commencement and Transitory Provisions Order 1936 cl.15(2)

respondent_arguments.text: Punjab Civil Services Rules 1941 r.1.4(ii) excludes Tehsildars as special provision under Tehsildari Rules.
Tehsildars not in Subordinate Services; no notification including them.

court_reasoning.text: Though s.9 amended deleting rule-making power, Tehsildari Rules 1932 saved by Adaptation Order cls.9,10; conditions of service continued by Transitory Order cl.15(2); Financial Commissioner authority preserved.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rules and powers continued until other provision made; not abrogated.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.7 Adaptation Order not apply as Financial Commissioner office continued, only powers adjusted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Applies where authority ceases to exist.

court_reasoning.text: 1941 Civil Services Rules issue not raised in High Court; no evidence Tehsildars in Subordinate Services or rules superseded Tehsildari Rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Cannot entertain new plea without notifications.

court_reasoning.text: Dissent (Raghubar Dayal J.): Tehsildari Rules inoperative post-1937 as inconsistent with s.241 GOI Act vesting power in Governor; para 7 Adaptation substitutes Governor; 1941 Rules apply as no special provision exception for services.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Power of appointment includes dismissal; Civil Rules govern Tehsildars.

holdings.text: Financial Commissioner invested with power to dismiss Tehsildar under continuing Tehsildari Rules 1932; dismissal valid.
Punjab Civil Services Rules 1941 effect not determinative as not raised below and no evidence of supersession.

precedents_cited.relevance: Repeal deems power never existed; rules without jurisdiction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Pradyut Kumar v. Chief Justice of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Power of appointment includes dismissal; continued application of old rules anomalous if inconsistent with new Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: North West Frontier Province v. Suraj Narain Anand
precedents_cited.relevance: Dismissal falls within conditions of service.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Land Revenue Act, 1887
statutes_cited.relevance: Original power to Financial Commissioner to make rules for Tehsildars; amended 1937 deleting rule-making power.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Appointments by Governor; continuation of laws; adaptation powers; transitory provisions.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India (Adaptation of Indian Laws) Order, 1937
statutes_cited.relevance: Saves rules, notifications, powers; substitutes corresponding authorities; does not invalidate prior acts.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India (Commencement and Transitory Provisions) Order, 1936
statutes_cited.relevance: Conditions of service continue until other provision made.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Writ petition; certificate; rule-making; continuation of services rules.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Civil Services Rules, 1941
statutes_cited.relevance: Apply to services unless special provision; competent authorities for penalties.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed with costs; majority holds Financial Commissioner had power to dismiss under continuing Tehsildari Rules; High Court order upheld. (Raghubar Dayal J. dissented, would allow appeal and restore single judge order).

key_quotes.text: Notwithstanding the abrogation of the powers of the Financial Commissioner to frame rules, the Tehsildari Rules, 1932 remained in force.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on continuation of rules post-1937 adaptation.

key_quotes.text: The power of appointment carries with it the power of dismissal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissent's key observation linking appointment to dismissal authority.

key_quotes.text: It is difficult for this Court to entertain any plea depending for its adjudication on notifications said to be issued by the Government from time to time, raised for the first time in appeal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejection of new argument on 1941 rules.
